awd_titl_txt: RoL: FELS: RAISE:  Collaborative Research:  Watershed Rules of Life
awd_abstract_narration:
Rivers are the circulatory systems of the continents, delivering land-derived water, pollutants and elements to the ocean.  They are also sites with unique organisms, food webs, and microbial communities that can transform these materials during transport to the ocean.  Microbes are the engines for these transformations, with considerable capacity to remove or alter important elements (e.g., carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, mercury, arsenic), produce greenhouse gasses, and support food webs. However, due to large changes in water flow from day to day, and the big differences in the types of streams and rivers across the landscape, understanding how riverine microbes impact the chemistry of rivers is difficult.  This project will research a set of "Watershed Rules of Life" that govern the establishment of riverine water column microbial communities that are critical to understanding rivers as circulatory systems.  The researchers have proposed a set of hypotheses that adds microbial ecology into the scaffolding of hydrology and geomorphology in order to research these Watershed Rules of Life.  The hypothesis will be tested by field work and modeling in a diverse set of watersheds throughout the United States.  The knowledge gained by these studies will allow for a broader understanding of rivers in both the U.S. and other temperate regions of the world.  The investigators will interact with the Yale New Haven Promise Internship program, which provides internships for students from New Haven interested in STEM. Professor Raymond will also interact with students at the Crested Butte Community School. This project will train graduate and undergraduate students at UMass, OSU and Yale. Findings will be incorporated into courses taught by the investigators.
 
The researchers will target the emergent property of microbial functional trait distributions across the physical templates of watersheds and in response to hydrologic variability.  The project will sample the Connecticut, Deschutes, Gunnison and Willamette watersheds, which are similar in size but differ in climate and geomorphology.  Within each watershed, sampling will focus on streams of different sizes, the impact of reservoirs and hydrologic variability. The proposed research will develop mathematical expressions that relate multiple indices for the development and activity of planktonic microbial communities to stream order, stream hydraulics (e.g., velocity and depth), flow variability, and temperature.  These indices will be based on metagenomics for genomic diversity, metatranscriptomics for gene expression, and microbial 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing for phylogenetic diversity in riverine samples.  Microbial indices will be compared to modeled estimates of the time scale for water column microbial community development (i.e., residence time) and microbial transformation rates (e.g., denitrification).  It is hypothesized that geomorphology (e.g., depth, velocity), discharge variability, and temperature are the main determinants of when and where distinct planktonic microbial riverine communities emerge in the water column of river networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Scientific Merit. We proposed to develop a set of rules of life for water column microbes in inland waters that leverages the dendritic nature of watersheds and established physical laws governing stream geomorphology, hydrology, and chemistry. In 1980, Vannote leveraged these physical laws to develop the River Continuum Concept (RCC) that continues to be used to conceptualize the structure and function of biological communities and infer how stream chemistry and biology co-develop along gradients in stream morphology. The original RCC did not include a model for microbial communities or their impact on carbon respiration and greenhouse gas release from rivers, but recent refinements in this concept, along with breakthroughs in geospatial data sets and microbial techniques, lay the groundwork for leveraging these ideas to develop watershed rules of microbial life. 

We studied 4 major watersheds (Connecticut, Gunnison, Willamette, and Deschutes Rivers), employing a nested sampling design targeting small, medium, and large order streams. We collected a suite of biogeochemical measurements, assessed microbial communities with multi-Omics (microbiome diversity, metagenomics, metatranscriptomics), quantified landscape characteristics with GIS tools, and collaborated with DOE WHONDRS to analyze dissolved organic matter (DOM) with FTICR Mass Spectrometry. We also modeled in-stream water residence times based on river reach length, water velocity, river discharge, and lake volume.

Our research showed that temperature and water residence time in river networks are master variables that control microbial community composition and the degree to which DOM is transformed to greenhouse gasses in river networks. These two variables control rates of microbial activity and growth (temperature) and the time available for microbes to grow and respire DOM (residence time).  We are developing Damköhler number indices based on temperature and residence time to serve as watershed rules of life that quantify the microbial community composition, microbial ecosystem function, DOM transformation, and CO2 evasion from river networks.

The major findings of this project are: 1. We determined that lakes and reservoirs are hot spots of CO2 release in river networks and developed a working CO2 efflux model to determine fluxes from satellite data in collaboration with the upcoming NASA SWOT mission; 2. We modeled dissolved organic carbon (DOC) photo-oxidation in the Connecticut watershed and found that it is a minor process compared to microbial respiration; 3. We conducted a global analysis of CO2 evasion from rivers, and developed a Damköhler number for DOC uptake in global river networks that distinguishes rivers that release carbon as CO2 from those that simply transport carbon downstream. 4. We found that microbial community composition varies most strongly with temperature and water residence time in river networks. 5. We found that the number of biochemical transformations of dissolved organic matter (DOM), predicted from detailed chemical characterizations, were also related to temperature and water residence time, and varied with Damköhler number for DOC uptake.

Broader Impacts. Understanding how microbial genetic and functional diversity interacts with DOM is important for predicting the impacts of land-use change, nutrient use, and shifting climate on local and global environmental cycles. The Watershed Rules of Life project produced large, publicly available datasets of microbiome DNA sequences and DOM chemistry from major U.S. rivers.  The project contributed to collaborations with scientists at the US DOE (PNNL, JGI), USGS, Colorado State University, University of Maryland. This project trained fourteen undergraduate interns at OSU including one Honors College student, two postdoctoral scientists, three Ph.D. graduate students, and three technicians whose professional development is strongly linked to this project, its objectives, and its publications. These young scientists learned to conduct their own research as part of a larger collaborative effort. This project also provided course material for use by the Principal Investigators, who teach undergraduate and graduate courses at their home institutions. Raymond also worked with 2 New Haven Promise students. The New Haven Promise program is a location-based scholarship program for residents and graduates of New Haven Public Schools and approved charter schools.  It is a partnership with Yale that works to identify and help place early college level STEM students into Yale research programs.  The program pulls 100% of its students from New Haven.  90% are students of color, 85% attend in state colleges, 70% are from households that earn under 60k, and 70% are first generation to college.  Raymond received an award from Yale in 2022 for this work.
